 <title>Government should pursue wealthy tax dodgers, not serve the rich and powerful </title>
 <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/rabble-news/~3/LUVU7G34OWE/government-should-pursue-wealthy-tax-dodgers-not-serve-rich-and-powerful</link>
 <description><div class="taxonomy-images"><a href="/category/bios/rabble-staff/contributor/murray-dobbin" class="taxonomy-image-links"><img src="http://rabble.ca/sites/rabble/files/imagecache/thumbnail/category_pictures/murray%20dobbin.jpg" alt="Murray Dobbin" title="Murray Dobbin" width="100" height="100" class="taxonomy-image-term-366 taxonomy-image-vid-14"/></a></div><div class="field field-type-date field-field-story-publish-date">

        </div>
</div>
<p><em>Like this article? rabble is reader-supported journalism. <a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank">Chip in</a> to keep stories like these coming.</em></p>
<p><a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank"><img src="/sites/rabble/files/node-images/donategreen.png" width="120" height="30" /></a></p>
<p>Note to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau:</p>
<p>We will not be distracted forever by your explanation of quantum computers and yoga poses. Or even by the admittedly impressive list of low-hanging fruit (the return of the long-form census, the inquiry into missing Aboriginal women) you have picked thanks to Stephen Harper.</p><div class="field field-type-text field-field-summary">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    Are Justin Trudeau&#039;s Liberals the same old Bay Street Party? The litmus test will be how he deals with tax law-breakers at accounting firm KPMG and their apologists in the Canada Revenue Agency.        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<p><a href="http://rabble.ca/columnists/2016/05/government-should-pursue-wealthy-tax-dodgers-not-serve-rich-and-powerful" target="_blank">read more</a></p><div class="feedflare">

 <title>RCMP turn a blind eye to abandoned firearms in Fort Mac -- manna to the gun lobby but a worry to the rest of us</title>
 <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/rabble-news/~3/O0BhAtg8d8A/rcmp-turn-blind-eye-to-abandoned-firearms-fort-mac-manna-to-gun-</link>
 <description><div class="story-teaser story-teaser-blog">

<div class="body"> 
   <p><em>Like this article? rabble is reader-supported journalism. <a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank">Chip in</a> to keep stories like these coming.</em></p>
<p><a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank"><img src="/sites/rabble/files/node-images/donategreen.png" width="120" height="30" /></a></p>
<p>We know firearms are dangerous -- especially when they're not in the hands of so-called "law-abiding gun owners," which would mean, I guess, they're either in the hands of "law-breaking gun owners" or plain old-fashioned thieves, who are presumably lawbreakers by default.</p>   <div class="read-more"></div>
</div>

 <title>Mother's Day, Fort McMurray, Ottawa and campus sexual assault: What's new in the news </title>
 <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/rabble-news/~3/eT-zmD764CU/mothers-day-fort-mcmurray-ottawa-and-campus-sexual-assault-whats</link>
 <description><div class="story-teaser story-teaser-blog">

<p>As the weather gets warmer it's the perfect time for a picnic or a cool mojito on a patio. But the news stops for no one from the Fort McMurray wildfire to the progress of Trudeau's campaign promises. <item>
 <title>What electoral system would you like to see in Canada?</title>
 <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/rabble-news/~3/rN_p83UWoQI/what-electoral-system-would-you-to-see-canada</link>
 <description><p>This week, the federal government <a href="http://rabble.ca/blogs/bloggers/karl-nerenberg/2016/05/trudeau-puts-electoral-reform-process-motion" target="_blank">started its review process</a> for ushering in electoral reform to Canada.</p>
<p>Justin Trudeau promised that 2015 would be the last election run under the country's current "first-past-the-post" system.</p>
<p>With many factors to consider -- gender balance, Indigenous representation, making every vote count -- what electoral system do you want to see implemented in Canada?</p><form action="/polls/what-electoral-system-would-you-to-see-canada"  accept-charset="UTF-8" method="post" id="advpoll-voting-binary-form-0" class="advpoll-vote">
<div><div class="poll">
  <div class="advpoll-available-choices">
    <div class="choice-header">Choices</div>
    <div class="vote-choices">
      <div class="form-checkboxes"><div class="form-item" id="edit-choice-1551-wrapper">
 <label class="option" for="edit-choice-1551"><input type="checkbox" name="choice[1551]" id="edit-choice-1551" value="1551"   class="form-checkbox" /> I've said it once, I'll say it again: Canada needs proportional representation.</label>
</div>
<div class="form-item" id="edit-choice-1552-wrapper">
 <label class="option" for="edit-choice-1552"><input type="checkbox" name="choice[1552]" id="edit-choice-1552" value="1552"   class="form-checkbox" /> Proportional representation, but more specifically mixed-member proportional.</label>
</div>
<div class="form-item" id="edit-choice-1553-wrapper">
 <label class="option" for="edit-choice-1553"><input type="checkbox" name="choice[1553]" id="edit-choice-1553" value="1553"   class="form-checkbox" /> Proportional representation, but more specifically Single Transferable Vote.</label>
</div>
<div class="form-item" id="edit-choice-1554-wrapper">
 <label class="option" for="edit-choice-1554"><input type="checkbox" name="choice[1554]" id="edit-choice-1554" value="1554"   class="form-checkbox" /> The preferential ballot system seems best.</label>
</div>
<div class="form-item" id="edit-choice-1555-wrapper">
 <label class="option" for="edit-choice-1555"><input type="checkbox" name="choice[1555]" id="edit-choice-1555" value="1555"   class="form-checkbox" /> I'm really confused by all the different electoral systems.</label>
</div>
<div class="form-item" id="edit-choice-1556-wrapper">
 <label class="option" for="edit-choice-1556"><input type="checkbox" name="choice[1556]" id="edit-choice-1556" value="1556"   class="form-checkbox" /> None of the above.</label>
</div>
</div>    </div>

<item>
 <title>The planet won't wait for a cautious transition to renewable energy</title>
 <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/rabble-news/~3/mWTqkAddPkA/planet-wont-wait-cautious-transition-to-renewable-energy</link>
 <description><div class="story-teaser story-teaser-blog">

<div class="body"> 
   <p><em>Like this article? rabble is reader-supported journalism. <a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank">Chip in</a> to keep stories like these coming.</em></p>
<p><a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank"><img src="/sites/rabble/files/node-images/donategreen.png" width="120" height="30" /></a></p>
<p>Something that I hear more and more these days is that the transition to renewable energy must be managed. It must be careful and planned and not rock the boat.</p>
<p>As the story goes, we cannot disrupt the economy too much in our enthusiasm to go green. Switching from first to fifth gear, they say, would threaten jobs, cause electricity prices to skyrocket, and generate too much upheaval in our still-fossil-fuel-dependent economies.</p>   <div class="read-more"></div>
</div>

</div><p><a href="http://rabble.ca/blogs/bloggers/views-expressed/2016/05/planet-wont-wait-cautious-transition-to-renewable-energy" target="_blank">read more</a></p><div class="feedflare">

<p>In this very moment, actions are taking place around the world to break away from fossil fuel dependency. This movement is part of the global <a href="https://breakfree2016.org/" rel="nofollow">Break Free Campaign.</a> From Nigeria to Brazil, New Zealand to Indonesia, Turkey to South Africa, a surge of people power is urging governments to keep oil, gas, and coal in the ground, and embrace a renewable energy future.</p>   <div class="read-more"></div>

 <title>In Canada's concentrated banking industry, what we need is a public bank</title>
 <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/rabble-news/~3/JE0rBPRl0YY/canadas-concentrated-banking-industry-what-we-need-public-bank</link>
 <description><div class="taxonomy-images"><a href="/category/bios/linda-mcquaig" class="taxonomy-image-links"><img src="http://rabble.ca/sites/rabble/files/imagecache/thumbnail/category_pictures/McQUAIG_new%20photo%20copy_0.jpg" alt="Linda McQuaig" title="Linda McQuaig" width="100" height="100" class="taxonomy-image-term-4934 taxonomy-image-vid-14"/></a></div><div class="field field-type-date field-field-story-publish-date">
    <div class="field-items">

        </div>
</div>
<div class="field field-type-filefield field-field-image-for-node">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <img src="http://rabble.ca/sites/rabble/files/imagecache/120-width-scaled/node-images/canada_post_truck.jpg" alt="Photo: Adityo Sastromuljono/flickr" title="Photo: Adityo Sastromuljono/flickr" width="120" height="84" class="imagecache imagecache-120-width-scaled imagecache-default imagecache-120-width-scaled_default"/>        </div>

<p><em>Like this article? rabble is reader-supported journalism. <a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank">Chip in</a> to keep stories like these coming.</em></p>
<p><a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank"><img src="/sites/rabble/files/node-images/donategreen.png" width="120" height="30" /></a></p>
<p>For those with a yacht or a Porsche, banks are warm, welcoming  places. But banks are considerably less hospitable to those needing  financial services that don't include "wealth management."</p>
<p>Indeed, for hundreds of thousands of Canadians who have no wealth to  manage and really aren't richer than they think, banks are increasingly  inaccessible places.</p><div class="field field-type-text field-field-summary">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    While the Trudeau government&#039;s review of Canada Post is primarily focused on the issue of reinstating home delivery, the prospect of postal banking may be the more far-reaching and intriguing idea.        </div>
        </div>
</div>

 <description><div class="story-teaser story-teaser-blog">

<p>Employment in Canada hit the pause button in April, with job losses in Alberta offset by gains in British Columbia, Newfoundland and Labrador and New Brunswick.</p>
<p>The unemployment rate remained at 7.1 per cent unchanged from March.</p>
<p>Ontario employment remained virtually unchanged, with a loss of about 3,000 jobs.</p>   <div class="read-more"></div>

 <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/rabble-news/~3/YAkytpN_i2E/trudeaus-uneven-response-to-fort-mcmurray-and-attawapiskat-sh</link>

<p>Two Canadian communities are in desperate crisis -- the terrifying wildfires that destroyed Fort McMurray, and the epidemic of attempted youth suicides on the Attawapiskat First Nations reserve.</p>
<p>The question arises: Why are billions of dollars being pumped in to deal with one crisis while the other is all but being ignored?</p>   <div class="read-more"></div>

<p>Canada has a democratic deficit that is fairly widely acknowledged. The "first past the post" electoral system denies the majority of people a voice in decision-making. <item>
 <title>Not Rex: Elegy for Fort Mac (and humanity)</title>
 <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/rabble-news/~3/QAGu_HivbR4/not-rex-elegy-fort-mac-and-humanity</link>
 <description><fieldset class="fieldgroup group-tv-guide"><div class="field field-type-text field-field-current-show">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    Is this show currently playing?        </div>
        </div>
</div>
</fieldset>
<div class="field field-type-date field-field-story-publish-date">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <span class="date-display-single">May 11, 2016</span>        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<div class="field field-type-text field-field-summary">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    Humberto &quot;Not Rex&quot; DaSilva decides to ask the big questions about the Fort McMurray fire be it &quot;too soon&quot; or not.        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<fieldset class="fieldgroup group-video-information"><div class="field field-type-emvideo field-field-embedded-video">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <div class="emvideo emvideo-video emvideo-youtube"><iframe id="media-youtube-html5-1" title="YouTube video player" class="media-youtube-html5" type="text/html" width="562" height="350" src="http://www.youtube.com/v/mRELu9iUeoE?hd=1" frameborder="0"></iframe>
</div>        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<div class="field field-type-link field-field-where-to-find">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mRELu9iUeoE&amp;feature=youtu.be" target="_blank">YouTube</a>        </div>
        </div>
</div>
</fieldset>
<p>Fort Mac Town is burning down.</p>
<p>Did a hot spring and a dry winter create this? Or perhaps a spark of dry lightening? Or was it the winds of climate change? Or is it too soon to ask any of these questions.</p>
<p>Humberto "Not Rex" DaSilva decides it is time to ask the big questions.</p><div class="feedflare">

<p>UPDATE: <em>The Liberal government has revealed details of the special House committee that will be charged with recommending a new electoral system. <item>
 <title>Ain't nothing like the real thing -- but virtual reality comes close</title>
 <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/rabble-news/~3/_aHicY9uH2g/aint-nothing-real-thing-virtual-reality-comes-close</link>
 <description><div class="story-teaser story-teaser-blog">

<div class="body"> 
   <p><em>Like this article? rabble is reader-supported journalism. <a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank">Chip in</a> to keep stories like these coming.</em></p>
<p><a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank"><img src="/sites/rabble/files/node-images/donategreen.png" width="120" height="30" /></a></p>
<p>The digital revolution is breaking new ground every day. Technology has a way of doing that. I remember when Hewlett-Packard introduced its first "laptop" computer, which stored a page and a half of writing. It revolutionized my life as a newspaper columnist, allowing me to write on planes or in a tent and submit articles through a phone. I never imagined the steady advances that would lead to today's powerful laptops, tablets and handheld computers.</p>   <div class="read-more"></div>
</div>

 <title>Rise up! 'Drawn to Change' illustrates Canadian labour's stories and struggles</title>
 <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/rabble-news/~3/3g_ThkoM3Zo/rise-drawn-to-change-illustrates-canadian-labours-stories-and-struggles</link>

<p><a href="https://secure.rabble.ca/donate/" target="_blank"><img src="/sites/rabble/files/node-images/donategreen.png" width="120" height="30" /></a></p>
<p>"Indeed, much of what we learn about history in school, at the movies or on the History channel revolved around the lives of individuals with the most money and power in society, such as monarchs, capitalists, and politicians. But workers' lives matter too; without our labour, society would cease to function. We are important agents of social transformation, and our power is magnified when we work together."</p><div class="field field-type-text field-field-summary">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    The Graphic History Collective illustrates an informative and illuminating timeline of Canada&#039;s complicated labour history. Consider this your call to arms.        </div>
        </div>
</div>
